issues.description: Class-level @RequestMapping media types for PersonResource differ between the template and the solution. The template declares consumes/produces = JSON-only, while the solution expands these to include both JSON and XML. This is a cross-artifact difference in the expected request/response media types for the same REST resource and could confuse students when they compare the template to the reference: they may wonder whether XML support is required or expected, or why the solution accepts additional media types.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the media type configuration consistent between template and solution. Either (a) update the template PersonResource class-level @RequestMapping to produce/consume the same media types as the solution (include both JSON and XML), or (b) keep JSON-only in the solution as well. Alternatively, remove the class-level consumes/produces and annotate individual endpoints if needed. Document the intended media types in the problem statement so students know whether XML support is expected.

issues.description: The problem statement contains a confusing instruction about which client entry point to run: it tells students to run Starter for the client side and explicitly says 'Do not run H05E01ClientApplication!'. However, the provided Starter class immediately launches H05E01ClientApplication. This contradictory guidance (do not run a class that Starter launches) may confuse students about the correct way to start the client and the reason for the prohibition.
issues.suggested_fix: Clarify the instructions in the problem statement. Either remove the 'Do not run H05E01ClientApplication!' sentence or explain why running H05E01ClientApplication directly is discouraged (for example, if Starter performs required setup). A clear single instruction 'Run Starter to start the client (which will launch H05E01ClientApplication)' will avoid confusion.

issues.description: The problem statement describes the PersonController methods as taking a Consumer<List<Note>> parameter (mentions 'Note' instead of 'Person'). This incorrectly names the generic type for the callback and conflicts with the template and solution code, which correctly use Consumer<List<Person>>. This typo can confuse students about the expected types and the mapping between the problem description and the code they must implement.
issues.suggested_fix: Correct the problem statement to refer to Consumer<List<Person>> (or generically 'a Consumer that accepts the internal list of Person objects') so the textual description matches the template and solution method signatures and removes the misleading reference to 'Note'.
